position.marginalia_text: Vir prudens, et cordatus: serius, et industrius.

marginalia.translation: A prudent, wise, serious and industrious man.

position.marginalia_text: { Abundè pra[e]ceptoru[m]: facto opus. Omnis laus in actione.

marginalia.translation: Abounding in precepts: it is necessary for the deed. All praise lies in the action.

position.marginalia_text: Quantus quantus esse potes; Semper esto Tantus.

marginalia.translation: You must always be as great as you can possibly be great.
The very act of art and dignity of virtue.

position.marginalia_text: Nihil indignum viro: omnia prudentia, fortiq[ue] viro planè dignissima. Semper etiam cogitandu[m], priuataru[m] virtutu[m] radicem esse Temperantiam; publicaru[m], Justitiam.

marginalia.translation: Nothing is unworthy to a man: all prudent things are clearly most worthy to a strong man. And the thing to be learned is that the root of private virtue is temperance, while the root of public virtue is justice.

position.marginalia_text: Pulchrum, Semper esse amabilem, et la[e]tum.

marginalia.translation: To be beautiful is always to be lovable and cheerful.

position.marginalia_text: planè Sordescit. Tristi, et timido nihil turpius.

marginalia.translation: it grows entirely base. For the sad and timid mad nothing is more ugly.

position.marginalia_text: Laudo virum in factis constantissimum, et planè virum: in dictis urbanum: in omni conuersatione humanissimum. In actione Laconicum: in oratione Atticum: in vtraq[ue] Romanum: in omni virili

marginalia.translation: I praise the man who is most constant in deed, and clearly is a man: cultivated in words, most refined in all conversation. Spartan in action, Attic in speech: Roman in both; most keen in all manly industriousness.
